text.body:
After looking online for a comprehensive, regional plant identifying app, I thought I could take some of the information from a number of resources and integrate them into a easy to use experience. I looked closely at how one would go about identifying a regional plant and went through the a user flow that could be fun, yet comprehensive. There are other functionalities that are in the works, such as sharing and personalized lists.

Logo design, user flow, icon design, and UI were all designed by myself.

For the holiday season, Tommy Bahama worked closely with Sweet Lady Jane Cakes to provide their popular Piña Colada cake for purchase online. I was asked with creating a landing page and other digital collateral, that would both explain a bit of the history of the cake, as well as be a portal to Sweet Lady Jane's site. With limited time and resources, I assisted in art directing the photoshoot for the images that would be used on the site and various other advertising applications.

Tommy Bahama's marketing team loves content dense index pages. I produced a number of different layouts that were stylized based on season. The following are a collection of some of the different index pages I helped create.

Tommy Bahama's mobile site was in need of a major facelift. Myself and another designer were tasked with redesigning the entire site.

With limited usability testing, we used well researched best-practices and heuristics to building out the 1.0 version of the mobile site. Shown are a few of the sketches and high-fidelity mocks.

The hope is that the mobile site will be used as a jumping off point to try and improve the interaction capabilities of the main site.

tbreskin.title: Tommy Bahama Site Re-Skin
captions: Cleaner more modern navigation to go with cleaner content (page content created by a team member, content art direction a collaboration with print and style guide provided by myself)
Product display page with cleaner aesthetic and simplified look
Previous versions of the website for comparison

text.body:
The main e-Commerce website for Tommy Bahama was being moved to a new platform and at the same time, it was getting a aesthetic refresh.

I was tasked at picking up this project that had been partially completed. While the previous owner of the project had done quite a bit of work, I had the disadvantage of not having a lot of background before being thrown into the project. Files were buried and I only had half the information, so I had to go through and make sure that consistency was put in place, so that future revisions could be made easier. I was responsible for final styling decisions and working with the developers to get changes done in a very short period of time.

An added obstacle in the site revision, was that, there were few layout changes that could be made. Aesthetic changes needed to be carefully considered, while maintaining business needs, and working within the restrictive technology platform. The ask was for the site to have a lighter, more modern aesthetic, while allowing the product to shine. Simplicity was the approach that I took, in order to let the product speak for itself. Some minor navigation changes helped declutter the home page, while navigation colors were consolidated to reflect a more cohesive and consistent visual language.

The Tommy Bahama careers page got a much needed facelift earlier this year.

I was tasked with creating a non-responsive website for desktop with limited ability to add interaction elements to the page. GIFs, rollovers and carousels were the only tools I had access to create something a little more elevated than our previous version.

The Swim Finder is a visual search function to help assist customers in finding the perfect swimsuit.

Designed with desktop, iPad and an 32 inch in-store touch display in mind, due to backend limitations, I had to make sure that a single non-responsive design worked across all these platforms.

text.body:
After the success of full-price site refresh, there was a business request to better align our off-price or outlet site with the look and feel of the full-price site. I was asked to restyle the entire outlet site, while maintaining the integrity of the content layout.

After experiencing some struggles and finding solutions while working on the main site refresh, I was able to streamline the redlining process, as well as produce a more comprehensive style guide for development.

The end result was a much cleaner and integrated look and feel than the previous version of the outlet site.

Tommy Bahama deploys out over 400 full-circulation emails a year (not including geo-targeted, triggered and transactional, or special events emails). I have done my fair share of all of them.

They range from simple templated emails to quick-turn custom messaging that are almost always on very tight turnaround schedules, with sometimes frequent revisions based on shifting marketing priorities. I found being nimble and asking questions always helped to get these churned out on time, with great design that met the requests of my business partners.

Seattle's fun and quirky Fremont neighborhood needed a digital portal where the Artwalk director and artists could digitally connect to plan monthly artwalks. It also needed to be a place where attendees could quickly find information.

I used illustrations of neighborhood icons and bright colors to capture the eccentricity of the neighborhood, while utilizing straightforward and easy navigation to make it simple for both participants and attendees to get the information they needed.

Development help provided by Andrew Burgess

Another project at Zumiez where the private label team was asked to design and produce was a price-point conscience private label longboard line.

I worked with buying team to create a logo, the the board shapes, and construction. Once we finalized the technical aspects with the manufacturer, we customized wheels and trucks and created various designs to go on the bottom sides of the boards.

While working in-house for the Zumiez private label team, I got the opportunity to work on a number of different apparel brands. Each brand targeted a different segment of a similar demographic. The brands--which catered to 13- to 25-year- old skateboarders and snowboarders--ran from technical to trendy, with a little bit of everything in between.

The samples seen here are just a few examples of apparel packaging that I designed during my tenure. Most packaging groups typically contained well over 50+ items per group, with 3-4 packaging groups developed at one time. I concepted, designed, created production files, tracked, worked with domestic and overseas vendors to produce samples, and made all final approvals.

In my free time, I freelance and volunteer with a number of promoters and organizations to create event promotions and posters, many of which had an accompanying flyer.. I would also sometimes create additional collateral including lapel pins, merch, and social media assets.

T-shirts were a staple business at Zumiez. 5-10 tees would be designed on a monthly basis, all of which had to be on-trend, and desirable.

On top of designing, I also created all of the technical packages that were sent to the manufacturers, which included all the measurements and details of the end product.

I worked directly with domestic and overseas vendors to get tees with my artwork produced.

There were also times when I was asked to work directly with third-party vendors, for whom I would provide art direction and trend analysis packages.

While on the Zumiez private label team, I also learned textile printing. My patterns adorned everything from apparel to backpacks, wallets, belts... the list goes on. I was able to utilize various types of techniques including sublimation, discharge printing, and screen printing, as well as large-scale engineered prints.

Shameless Productions wanted to move beyond club nights and hired me to help design their first album cover, a logo revamp, and all the collateral that came along with that. On top of the album artwork, I also did all social and online advertising assets, posters, flyers, and merchandise graphics.

The Planet is a campus environmental magazine produced by students at Western Washington University. I helped design multi-page layouts and covers for a number of articles. I worked closely with another designer to create cohesive text, image and stylistic treatments that tied each issue together. We worked closely with writers, photographers, printers, and editors to produce this quarterly magazine.

text.body: This annual picnic needed a simple RSVP card for guests to send back with important information for the host. It was inspired by vintage fireworks packaging.
